subNodes.conversationText:
On the other side of the door was a masive semicircular chamber with coliseum seating. A large throne stood in the middle of a raised platform below, and numerous high-looking officials of the Congress stood or sat on either side of it.

<FirstName> could just see what appeared to be a rather large but ordinary moth sitting there.

Despite the Chamber's size, there wasn't much room. Thousands of the beings were in attendance, stuffed into seats and standing (or frolicking) in the aisles. The censor and the rest of the young witch's escort had disappeared after the fight. Knott stood nearby, vigilant. Pharaoh, unnerved, kept close to the witch, perching on <his/her> shoulder with his head half-tucked into a wing.

"Order, order," intoned one of the officials below. "A petitioner comes before us. The Mouth of the House will hear what <he/she> has to say." He bowed slightly to the moth on the pillow. "I, the Speaker of the Mouth, will translate."

The Speaker of the Mouth conferred with the moth on the cushion and then addressed the crowd. “I would refer the members crying out for the petitioner's death to Codex Interruptus, Statute 7: A new petitioner standing before the Congress must not be killed on sight."
"This petitioner is the YOUNG WITCH, all caps. I move that we amend the Codex.”

The Speaker of the Mouth conferred again with the moth again before responding. "Motion denied. Codices in Bodices: Congressional Arcana for the Vulgar Lawmaker, Condensed, in the chapter on amendments, says, Put partisan politics above the law and high drama above partisan politics -- page 49. This is high drama; ergo, no amendment.”
<FirstName>'s opponent conferred with some other members of the Congress next to her.
"We move to amend Codices in Bodices with pertinent scribbles to the margins."

"Motion deferred until member pays fines for certain overdue items borrowed from the Library of the Congress of Moths."

This announcement seemed to carry a lot of weight. There were gasps in the crowd, and some of the beings fainted and had to be carried out of the Chamber on stretchers.
<He/She> felt all eyes in the Chamber on <him/her>. Soon <he/she> was standing before the Speaker.
<He/She> recalled a passage from the tomes in the antechamber: "I come to this august body with an inquiry..."
"I'll show you an August body, witch" said <FirstName>'s enemy petulantly.
"Can a censor with a poniard please take care of that fool if she interrupts again?" said the Speaker. "Now, what was it you were saying?" he asked the young witch.
"I want to find out who killed Nnenne. The kami told me you knew."
"Speak up, speak up! You're wasting our time!"
"I want to find out who killed Nnenne. The kami told me you knew."
"Hear me, Congress of Moths! I seek a murderer."
"That's not how you address the Chamber!" someone said fiercely.
"Petitioners are not held to our standards," said the Speaker, dismissing the remark. "Now, what was it you were saying?" he asked the young witch.
"I want to find out who killed Nnenne. The kami told me you knew."
"But why? Who's Eris? Where does she live?"
"North of the swamp, not far from the kami's cave. You should be more thorough."
"I've seen a letter from Eris to Nnenne. It said she was worried about her. Why did she shoot her?"
"A letter, you say? Was it addressed Dear Nnenne? Dear me," mocked 's opponent.
Something about the redcap's remark was very funny to everyone else in the Chamber, and they all laughed, even the Speaker.
"Well well, young witch. You've had your question answered. You have what you came for. Time to leave."

The antagonistic redcap stood up.

"Leave? Now that the petitioner’s petition has been satisfied, petitioner has no petition, and is therefore no longer a petitioner. The statute no longer protects <him/her>. I move that we kill <him/her>."
"Hmm... This motion is not without a certain whiff of logic. I will allow the Chamber a few moments of pivotal deliberation."
The redcap shot <FirstName> a wicked look of triumph.

But before deliberations could really begin -- deliberations that, if they went in the redcap's direction, would certainly mean <FirstName>'s death at the hands of thousands of members of the Congress of Moths -- the young witch, summoning all <his/her> courage, brought the Chamber to a halt.
It was Sieben, the enigmatic purveyor of dross.
"We didn't fully answer the petitioner's question. The petitioner remains unsatisfied, and therefore remains a petitioner."
"So be it," said the Speaker of the Mouth after a few moments. "There will be no deliberations. The redcap is overruled. The young witch is to know more."
The assembly flew into a rage.
"Order, order. Usher, open the door to June."
"June enough to answer the petitioner's question," he said irritably.

A contingent of serjeants-at-arms and their chief, a brawny sturjeon, led the young witch and her companions through the seething throng, sometimes whacking the clamoring members of the Congress with the backs of their swords.

Soon they stood before a door to the upper world.
"I remain unsatisfied," <he/she> said, <his/her> voice booming. "I am still a petitioner. I demand to know more."
The witch's audacity stunned the Congress of Moths. The Speaker glared at <him/her>.
"More? That's a word I've heard before. Your new petition is denied. Do you have anything else to say before the deliberations that inevitably lead to your demise?"
"I am a witch of tremendous power. How many of your kind have I slain? You may overpower me, but you will suffer before you do."
"This House is a mockery of justice. This is all nonsense -- arbitrary, tyrannical nonsense."
"One thing only. Why does the Congress speak in poems in the world above and in prose down here?"
"Two bodies, one branch," said the Speaker, shrugging.
The witch's final question bored the Chamber. Murmurs spread through the room. Deliberations were beginning.
"I am a witch of tremendous power. How many of your kind have I slain? You may overpower me, but you will suffer before you do."
Those beings closest to the young witch shrank back. The waves of the Secret Sea grew louder. <FirstName> felt nearly equal to the battle <he/she> now expected.
"This House is a mockery of justice. This is all nonsense -- arbitrary, tyrannical nonsense."
But then the moth on the throne -- the Mouth of the House -- fluttered into the air. It landed near the Speaker's ear, and for some time sat there, communicating with him.
"So be it," said the Speaker of the Mouth after a few moments. "There will be no deliberations. The redcap is overruled. The young witch is to know more."
"I expected more. Is this all the illustrious Congress of Moths can give me? A name?"
The witch's audacity stunned the Congress of Moths. The Speaker glared at <him/her>.
"I come here at the behest of the kami and am under their protection," said <FirstName> half-truthfully. "They promised more from you."
The witch's audacity stunned the Congress of Moths. The Speaker glared at <him/her>.
<FirstName> nodded. <He/She> had thought as much. But why had she done it?
"Well well, young witch. You've had your question answered. You have what you came for. Time to leave."
<FirstName> nodded. <He/She> would have to find this Eris. How had it all happened?
"Well well, young witch. You've had your question answered. You have what you came for. Time to leave."
<FirstName> felt a new pang of regret for the blood <he/she>'d taken. If only <he/she>'d known before.
"Well well, young witch. You've had your question answered. You have what you came for. Time to leave."
"Get down here! The Mouth of the House will not be able to hear you up there."

The room erupted in laughter. The redcap who seemed to hate <him/her> so much whooped and jeered.

<FirstName> obeyed, Knott and Pharaoh following <him/her>. Soon <he/she> was standing before the Speaker.
<He/She> recalled a passage from the tomes in the antechamber: "I come to this august body with an inquiry..."
"Hear me, Congress of Moths! I seek a murderer."
